text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

Editorial changes have been made throughout this entire section to conform to the new internal and management control standards and to support research in electronic media. Substantive changes have been made to each subsection to address appropriate reference material, organizational terms, titles, and clarify existing procedures according to current policies and procedures.
Web references were added/updated throughout to support research in electronic media.
11.3.39.1.1 through 11.3.39.1.4 – Added subsections to align content for background, authority, resources and responsibilities.

IRM 11.3.39.3 – Revised title from “Responsibilities” to “Deﬁnitions” and content originally found IRM 11.3.39.5 to align and deﬁne terminology used throughout this section. OMB Circular A-108 modiﬁed terminology for computer matching agreements from “new” to “establishment,” from “extension” to “renewal’, from “renewal” to “re-establishment” and from “revision” to ‘modiﬁcation.”
IRM 11.3.39.4 – Revised title from “Scope” to “Categories of Subjects Covered by CMPPA” and content previously addressed in IRM 11.3.39.6.
) IRM
– Added subsection titled “Written Agreements” and revised and aligned content previously addressed in IRM
Removed reference to Exhibit
Revised language to clarify actions required by OMB Circular A-
) IRM
– Added subsection titled “Matching Program Notice and Reporting Requirements” and revised and aligned content previously addressed in IRM
Revised language to support OMB Circular A-
requirements regarding time frames for reporting matching programs to OMB and Congress and Federal Register Notice publication. (
) IRM
– Added subsection titled “Notice to Records Subjects” and revised and aligned content previously addressed in IRM
Removed reference to TIGTA preparing the Federal Register Notice for matches it conducts involving IRS employees. The Inspector General Empowerment Act of
includes an exemption for the Inspector General (IG) to the Computer Matching and Privacy Protection Act of
(CMPPA). This exemption excuses Inspector Generals from obtaining formal matching agreements before matching data with other agencies and entities to identify fraud and waste. (
) IRM
– Revised title from “Matching Programs Covered by CMA” to “Annual Matching Activity Review and Report” and added content to support annual reporting actions as required by OMB Circular A-
) IRM
– Removed subsection.

IRM 11.3.39.6.2 – Added subsection titled “Matching Program Notice and Reporting Requirements” and revised and aligned content previously addressed in IRM 11.3.39.8.2. Revised language to support OMB Circular A-108 requirements regarding time frames for reporting matching programs to OMB and Congress and Federal Register Notice publication.

IRM 11.3.39.6.3 – Added subsection titled “Notice to Records Subjects” and revised and aligned content previously addressed in IRM 11.3.39.8.3. Removed reference to TIGTA preparing the Register Notice for matches it conducts involving IRS employees. The Inspector General Empowerment Act of 2016 includes an exemption for the Inspector General (IG) to the Computer Matching and Privacy Protection Act of 1988 (CMPPA). This exemption excuses Inspector Generals from obtaining formal matching agreements before matching data with other agencies and entities identify fraud and waste.

IRM 11.3.39.7 – Revised title from “Matching Programs Covered by CMA” to “Annual Matching Activity Review and Report” and added content to support annual reporting actions as required OMB Circular A-108.
IRM 11.3.39.7.1 – Removed subsection.
Exhibit 11.3.39-1, 11.3.39-2 and 11.3.39-3 – Deleted exhibits; sample agreements can be obtained through Data Services via e-mail to GLDS.CMPPA@irs.gov.
IRM 11.3.39 dated September 17, 2013 is superseded.
All Operating Divisions and Functions.
The Disclosure and Privacy Knowledge Base can be found at: https://portal.ds.irsnet.gov/sites/vl003/pages/default.aspx
Table of Contents
Matching and Privacy Protection Act 11.3.39 page
) Purpose: This IRM section provides an overview of and provisional for Public Law (PL)
, The Computer Matching and Privacy Scope and Act of
; hereafter referred to as CMPPA. The CMPPA amended the Privacy Act of
U.S.C. §

a) and adds certain protections for the subjects of Privacy Act records whose records are used in automated programs. These protections have been mandated to ensure: • Procedural uniformity in carrying out matching programs • Due process for subjects in order to protect their rights • Oversight of matching programs through the establishment of Data Integrity Boards at each agency engaging in matching to monitor the agency’s matching activity (
) Scope: The CMPPA is codiﬁed as part of the Privacy Act (
U.S.C. §

a) and: • Applies primarily to all federal agencies subject to the Privacy Act; • Brings non-federal agencies within the ambit of the Privacy Act when they are engaging in certain types of matching activities in with a federal agency that is subject to the Privacy Act; and a system of records is involved in the match; • Applies to a broad range of federal agency computer matching when the objective may affect an individual’s rights, beneﬁts and/or privileges; and • Is not intended to prevent the match of any computerized data for there exists legal authority and which is deemed the most method of achieving a desired objective; administrative controls are tablished to ensure privacy, integrity and veriﬁcation of data for computer matching programs. Note: The CMPPA does not extend Privacy Act coverage to those originally included.
Applies primarily to all federal agencies subject to the Privacy Act; Brings non

federal agencies within the ambit of the Privacy Act when they are engaging in certain types of matching activities in conjunction with a federal agency that is subject to the Privacy Act; and a federal system of records is involved in the match; Applies to a broad range of federal agency computer matching activities when the objective may affect an individual’s rights, beneﬁts and/or privileges; and Is not intended to prevent the match of any computerized data for which there exists legal authority and which is deemed the most appropriate method of achieving a desired objective; administrative controls are es
tablished to ensure privacy, integrity and veriﬁcation of data disclosed for computer matching programs.
Note: The CMPPA does not extend Privacy Act coverage to those not originally included.
) Audience: This IRM provides procedures applicable to all IRS Operating Divisions and Functions. (
) Policy Owner: Data Services, under Office of Governmental Liaison, sure and Safeguards (GLDS), is responsible for administering CMPPA guidelines. (
) Program Owner: Office of GLDS, under Privacy, Governmental Liaison Disclosure (PGLD), is responsible for oversight of CMPPA guidelines. (
) One of the forces driving the Privacy Act of

into existence was sional concern about the governments’ use of computers in which to keep records about individuals. The Act’s preamble points out the possibility of automated recordkeeping greatly magnifying the potential harm to record subjects. (

) Due to the steady automation of government programs, automated records play a signiﬁcant and pervasive role in federal recordkeeping. The CMPPA the ﬁrst amendment to the Privacy Act to address the concern of records impacting individual privacy by establishing protections, including public and individual notice, when information an individual provides to one government agency is matched with records from another agency for a different purpose.
Program Owner: Office of GLDS, under Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure (PGLD), is responsible for oversight of CMPPA guidelines.

Matching and Privacy Protection Act 11.3.39 page
of IRS security and conﬁdentiality requirements for federal and state agencies receiving Federal Tax Return and Return Information, collectively referred to as Federal Tax Information (FTI).
Please see IRM 1.1.27, Organization and Staffing, Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure (PGLD), for additional information regarding functional statements and management controls.

) The Office of Privacy Policy and Compliance (PPC) is responsible for Privacy Act oversight, ensuring the IRS implements sound policies designed protect the identity and privacy of employees and taxpayers. (

) The Office of Governmental Liaison, Disclosure and Safeguards (GLDS) responsible for overseeing the computer matching provisions of the CMPPA, ensuring FTI is appropriately disclosed and ensuring FTI provided to federal, state and local agencies remains conﬁdential. Through its functions, GLDS provides administration, guidance, support and technical assistance to the IRS Business and Functional Operating Division (BOD/FOD), as owner of the records, in the development of computer matching programs, agreements, notices and reports. a. Data Services is responsible for administering IRS matching programs covered by the CMPPA and will coordinate all activities associated with initiating and continuing matching programs subject to the CMPPA provi- sions within the IRS, including matches that involve internal records (personnel) that are subject to the CMPPA. b. Governmental Liaison is responsible for facilitating the exchange of data and fostering partnerships with Federal, state and local government agencies to improve tax administration, in accordance with IRM
, Policy Statement
(Formerly P-

). c. Disclosure is responsible for providing guidance and technical assis- tance in determining if matching programs are subject to the computer matching provisions, and if so, provide guidance in the technical review of required documents, notices and reports. d. Safeguards is responsible for ensuring that agencies and their contrac- tors, who have access to FTI from the IRS maintain adequate for the protection of such information. (
) The Business and Functional Operating Division (BOD/FOD), as owner of the records, is responsible for contacting Data Services, via e-mail a

LDS. CMPPA@irs.gov, to coordinate and prepare notices and reports required and appropriate for CMPPA matching program participation. Coordination will in- clude, but is not limited to: • Drafting the Computer Matching Agreement (CMA) language; • Obtaining the necessary reviews and approvals; • Ensuring each agency obtains approval from its respective Data Integ- rity Board (DIB) for matching agreements at the Federal level; • Reviewing existing and proposed matching programs periodically to de- termine if they are subject to and in compliance with the CMPPA; and • Completing the requirements for covered matching programs as cited
U.S.C. §
a(o), (p) and (r). (

protect the identity and privacy of employees and taxpayers. • Drafting the Computer Matching Agreement (CMA) language; • Obtaining the necessary reviews and approvals; • Ensuring each agency obtains approval from its respective Data Integ- rity Board (DIB) for matching agreements at the Federal level; • Reviewing existing and proposed matching programs periodically to de- termine if they are subject to and in compliance with the CMPPA; and • Completing the requirements for covered matching programs as cited in

a(o), (p) and (r).
With the increase in the number of record systems being developed locally, and the IRS’s move toward more cooperative activities with state and local
11.3 Disclosure of Official Information

agencies, the potential has increased that matches with non-federal at the area and territory levels may also be subject to the CMPPA is incumbent on Field Disclosure personnel to become familiar with the sions of the CMPPA so they can advise and assist with achieving with the CMPPA when a covered match is identiﬁed.

Computer Matching Agreement - written agreement between the source agency and the recipient agency (or non-federal agency) specifying the terms for parties engaging in a matching program. There are four types of CMAs: Establishment, Renewal, Re-establishment, and Modiﬁcation.

) Cost/Beneﬁt Analysis - the CMPPA requires a cost/beneﬁt analysis be of an agency’s decision to conduct or participate in a matching program. It must be included in matching agreements as justiﬁcation of the proposed matching program and include a “speciﬁc estimate of any savings.” The analysis is also used by the DIB in review process. Statutorily mandated matches do not have to reﬂect a positive cost beneﬁt in order to be by the DIB. (

) Data Integrity Board (DIB) - is established at the departmental level, of senior agency officials and is responsible for review and approval (or proval) of matching agreements and proposed matching programs. (

) Matching program - is the computerized comparison of two or more automated systems of records, or of a system of records with non-federal records. The records must exist in automated form or be converted to automated form to perform the match. A single matching program may several matches among a number of participants. (
) Non-Federal agency - is a state or local governmental agency that records contained in a system of records from a federal agency. (

) Recipient agency - is the federal agency (or its contractor) that receives records from a Privacy Act system of records of another federal agency or from state and/or local government to be used in a matching program. (

) Source agency - is the federal agency that discloses records from a records to another federal agency or to a state or local governmental to be used in a matching program. It can also be a non-federal agency discloses records to a federal agency to be used in a matching program. (

) Federal beneﬁt program applicants (individuals initially applying for Note: The Congress intends that federal employees be treated as of Subjects a federal beneﬁt program because of their employment by the by CMPPA (
) Federal beneﬁt program beneﬁciaries (individuals who actually receive beneﬁts). (
) Providers of services to assistance programs (those who are not the beneﬁciaries of federal beneﬁts programs, but may derive income from e.g., health care providers). (
) Federal employees in danger of adverse and/or disciplinary action. (
) Only Federal beneﬁt programs (including programs administered by states behalf of the federal government) providing cash or in-kind assistance to Programs viduals are covered. by CMPPA (

11.3 Disclosure of Official Information

Publication of the matching notice in the Federal Register is required at least 30 days prior to the effective date of the Modiﬁed CMA. Expires at 18 months but may be renewed for an additional 12 months.
Cost/Beneﬁt Analysis

the CMPPA requires a cost/beneﬁt analysis be of an agency’s decision to conduct or participate in a matching program. It must be included in matching agreements as justiﬁcation of the proposed matching program and include a “speciﬁc estimate of any savings.” The analysis is also used by the DIB in review process. Statutorily mandated matches do not have to reﬂect a positive cost beneﬁt in order to be approved by the DIB.
Note: The Congress intends that federal employees be treated as beneﬁciaries of a federal beneﬁt program because of their employment by the government.
) Federal beneﬁt program beneﬁciaries (individuals who actually receive beneﬁts). (
) Providers of services to assistance programs (those who are not the beneﬁciaries of federal beneﬁts programs, but may derive income from e.g., health care providers). (
) Federal employees in danger of adverse and/or disciplinary action. (
) Only Federal beneﬁt programs (including programs administered by states behalf of the federal government) providing cash or in-kind assistance to viduals are covered. (
) The purpose of the match must include one or more of the following:
Only Federal beneﬁt programs (including programs administered by states on behalf of the federal government) providing cash or in-kind assistance to indi-
The purpose of the match must include one or more of the following:
and Privacy Protection Act

• Establishing or verifying initial or continuing eligibility for federal programs. • Verifying compliance with the requirements, either statutory or tory, of federal beneﬁt programs. • Recouping payments or delinquent debts under federal beneﬁt programs. (
) The federal beneﬁt program or federal system of records need not be the source of data for a matching program to be covered by the CMPPA provi- sions. (

) Federal personnel or payroll record matches conducted for the purpose of, with an intended consequence of, taking adverse ﬁnancial, personnel, or plinary or other adverse action against federal personnel or any individual, subject to the CMPPA. This is the case even though these matches often place within a single agency. (
) Programs using records about subjects who are not individuals as deﬁned U.S.C. §
a(a)(
) are not covered. (

) The four elements must all be present before a matching program is under the provisions of the CMPPA. The provisions are: • Computerized comparison • Categories of subjects • Federal beneﬁt program • Matching purpose (

) Certain matching programs are exempt from the requirements of the For disclosure purposes, the most pertinent exemptions are those which exclude matches done for the purposes of: • Tax refund offset • Tax administration • IRC §

) Although the CMPPA exempts matches performed for tax administration purposes, OMB ﬁnal guidance on implementing the provisions of the expressly states that matches for management of the IRS workforce are included in the Act’s exemption of matching program requirements for tax ministration purposes. (

) The CMPPA does not exclude matches conducted by an agency using only records from systems of records maintained by that agency; if the purpose the match is not to take any adverse ﬁnancial, personnel, disciplinary, or adverse action against Federal personnel. Note: This means that matches only using IRS Privacy Act systems of records that may result in adverse action against the IRS workforce are not from the Act’s matching requirements. (
) Matches involving Federal employees conducted by Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration (TIGTA) are exempt from the CMPPA under Inspector General Act of
, as amended by the Inspector General erment Act of
(P.L.
). Internal Revenue Manual

tory, of federal beneﬁt programs. Recouping payments or delinquent debts under federal beneﬁt programs.

11.3.39.5.1 (07-19-2019) Exempt Matching Programs
11.3 Disclosure of Official Information
See 5 U.S.C. §552a(a)(8)(B) for the complete list of exempt matches.
• Develop, negotiate, execute and obtain approval of a written agreement, prepared in conformance with
USC §

a(o), and with the other agency or other IRS function. • Partner with IRS Information Technology (IT) management and staffs to determine system, programming and scheduling requirements. • Provide notice of the matching program to record subjects. • Prepare a report to Congress on the new matching program. • Prepare any Federal Register notice and report required (unless
Caution: Matching programs involving an IRS system of records must have a published routine use covering the matching activity.
11.3.39.6.1 (07-19-2019) Written Agreements
Pursuant to
U.S.C. §

a(o), no record which is contained in a system records may be disclosed for use in a computer matching program except pursuant to a CMA between the agencies. IRS frequently conducts the same matching program for several different agencies; the match for each agency is considered a single matching thus requiring a CMA with each agency. The type of CMA shall be determined in accordance with OMB Circular and identiﬁed in IRM

a. Establishment b. Renewal c. Re-establishment d. Modiﬁcation Data Services will coordinate with the BOD/FOD to appropriately draft negotiate the CMA language with the other agency or other IRS function. According to the CMPPA, the CMA must specify the following: a. Purpose and legal authority for conducting the program. b. Justiﬁcation for the program and anticipated results, including a estimate of any savings. c. Description of the records that will be matched, including each data element that will be used, the approximate number of records that matched, and the projected starting and completion dates of the program. d. Procedures for providing individualized notice to applicants for and ents of ﬁnancial assistance or payments under federal beneﬁts and applicants for and holders of positions as federal personnel at time of the application, and notice periodically thereafter. e. Procedures for verifying information produced in the matching f. Procedures for the retention and timely destruction of identiﬁable created by a recipient agency or non-federal agency in the matching program.

Purpose and legal authority for conducting the program. Justiﬁcation for the program and anticipated results, including a speciﬁc estimate of any savings. Description of the records that will be matched, including each data element that will be used, the approximate number of records that will matched, and the projected starting and completion dates of the program. Procedures for providing individualized notice to applicants for and ents of ﬁnancial assistance or payments under federal beneﬁts and applicants for and holders of positions as federal personnel at the time of the application, and notice periodically thereafter. Procedures for verifying information produced in the matching program. Procedures for the retention and timely destruction of identiﬁable records created by a recipient agency or non
federal agency in the matching program.

are created and main- tained by the Office of the Commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, and speciﬁed current and predecessor offices, this Schedule is intended to be functional in nature and can be used other IRS functions.

tained by the Office of the Commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, and speciﬁed current and predecessor offices, this Schedule is intended to be functional in nature and can be used other IRS functions. g. Procedures for ensuring the administrative, technical and physical security of the records matched and the results of the program. h. Prohibitions on duplication and redisclosure of records provided by the source agency within or outside the recipient agency or the non-federal agency, except where required by law or essential to the conduct of the matching program. i. Information on assessments that have been made on the accuracy of records that will be used in such a matching program. j. The Comptroller General may have access to all records of a recipient agency or a non-federal agency that the Comptroller General deems necessary in order to monitor or verify compliance with the agreement. ) After each party to the CMA concurs with the agreement language, the ﬁnal draft will be signed by the responsible official for each agency, at least

days prior to scheduled implementation of the matching program. The sible official is considered the system manager or the head of the organizational unit who has delegated authority to perform Privacy Act activi- ties in accordance with Treasury Directive

) Data Services will submit the CMA, signed by each party to the CMA, to the Treasury DIB, via e-mail to Privacy@treasury.gov for review and approval by the Board. In accordance with Treasury Directive

11.3 Disclosure of Official Information
porting to Congress and OMB of the matching program; this action shall occur at the agency level, rather than the sub-agency, component, or pro- gram level. (

) When preparing the CMA, Data Services and the BOD/FOD must consider systems of records to be used in the matching program. The routine use in the existing system notice must encompass the proposed matching program. If not, the system notice must be republished to modify the routine use statement prior to submitting the CMA for review by the Treasury DIB. (
) In addition, the data resulting from the matching program must be If the data match results in a new system of records, then a new system must also be published. (
) The initial CMA may remain in effect for a period not to exceed
months. During the last
days of the existing CMA, the parties to the CMA may approve a one-time renewal, not to exceed
months. The renewal CMA not require notice and reports to Congress and OMB and publication in the Federal Register. (
) Upon expiration of the initial CMA and one-time renewal CMA, a re- establishment CMA must be secured to continue the matching program. A re- establishment CMA must be fully executed within the last

days of the original CMA, or renewal CMA, if applicable. The re-establishment CMA requires the same notice, reporting and publication requirements as the initial CMA. The format for the initial CMA shall be used for the re-establishment CMA. (
) Agencies participating in matching programs that are subject to CMPPA are required to publish a matching notice in the Federal Register at least
prior to the establishment, re-establishment, or signiﬁcant modiﬁcation of the matching program. Examples of signiﬁcant modiﬁcations are cited in OMB cular A-

a. Generally, the recipient federal agency (or the source federal agency in match conducted with a non-federal agency) is responsible for notice of the matching program in the Federal Register. However, in matching programs involving only federal agencies, the agencies may assign responsibility. In the case of matching programs conducted with non-federal agency, the federal agency is responsible for publishing. b. Notice is not required for the one-year renewal of a matching program the agency’s DIB. (
) Agencies are required to report to OMB and Congress any proposal to establish, re-establish, or signiﬁcantly modify a matching program at least

days prior to the submission of the notice to the Federal Register for publica- tion. a. (

) When IRS is the recipient agency (or federal agency when the matching program is conducted with a non-federal agency), IRS will notify records subjects in one of two ways, either by constructive notice or direct notice. a. Constructive Notice - IRS will coordinate with Treasury to publish structive notice of the matching program in the Federal Register informing record subjects of the proposed matching program and in ac- cordance with
USC §
a(e) and OMB Circular A-

, and in the mat prescribed by the Federal Register Document Drafting Handbook. b. Direct Notice - IRS will provide to each individual in the match popula- tion a direct notice of the match. This may be accomplished by a state- ment on an application form or by separate document. In most amending the Privacy Act statement on an application form will meet CMPPA requirements. (
) For IRS matching programs designed to detect fraud and/or illegal acts of agency employees, IRS will ensure that direct notice is provided to each record subject. While Document

, Internal Revenue Service Ethics Handbook , universally prohibits fraud or inappropriate actions on the part of employees, a speciﬁc notice to each record subject regarding the matching program will be provided prior to the implementation of the matching and, at the least, an annual notice during the period the matching program is authorized. Note: TIGTA investigations are not part of the scope of matching programs for which employees will get notice, as TIGTA’s matching programs have exempted from the CMPPA by P.L.

) Notice published in the Federal Register should contain the following tion: a. Name of participating agency or agencies. b. Purpose of the match. c. Authority for conducting the match. d. Categories of records and individuals covered. e. Inclusive dates of the matching program. f. Address for receipt of public comment or inquiries. (
) IRS must publish notices of the establishment, re-establishment or of a matching program in the Federal Register at least
days prior to con- ducting the matching program. Internal Revenue Manual

11.3 Disclosure of Official Information

) Annually, Data Services will conduct a servicewide review of that year’s CMPPA covered matching program activities and prepare an annual report of the matching programs for IRS. The annual report will be submitted to the partment of Treasury Senior Agency Official for Privacy to be included in Treasury’s annual report to OMB. (
) Per OMB Circular A-

, the report shall include a list of each matching pro- gram in which the agency participated during the year. For each matching gram, the report shall include: a. A brief description of the matching program, including the names of all participating Federal and non-Federal agencies. b. Links to the matching notice. c. An account of whether the agency has fully adhered to the terms of the CMA. d. An account of whether all disclosures of agency records for use in the matching program continue to be justiﬁed. e. An indication of whether a cost-beneﬁt analysis was performed, the re- sults of the cost-beneﬁt analysis, and an explanation of why the agency proceeded with any matching program for which the results of the cost- beneﬁt analysis did not demonstrate that the program is likely to be cost effective. f. A description of any CMA that the DIB disapproved and the reasons for the disapproval. g. A description of any violations of matching agreements that have been alleged or identiﬁed, and a discussion of any action taken in response. (
) Data Services maintains CMAs with approximately
federal, state and local agencies, initially developed for master ﬁle extract programs that were in with government entities when the CMPPA was enacted.

federal, state and agencies, initially developed for master ﬁle extract programs that were in with government entities when the CMPPA was enacted. (

) The CMAs maintained by Data Services cover various matching programs involving the disclosure of FTI. For example, one matching program provides address information to enable federal agencies to locate individuals to monies, while another provides income information for use in determining bility for federal beneﬁt programs. IRS Data Loss Prevention Matching Program - IRS has the ity to ensure that information is kept conﬁdential as required by the Internal Revenue Code, Privacy Act of
, the Bank Secrecy Act, Title

of the United States Code, The Federal Information Security Modern- ization Act (FISMA), and other applicable laws that require safeguarding of information. Conﬁdential information that is sent without sufficient pro- tection is a violation of IRS Security Policy. The IRS matches computerized data to detect and deter breaches of security policy by IRS employees, contractors, or other individuals who have been granted access to IRS information, or to IRS equipment and resources, who send electronic communications in an unsecure and unencrypted manner.
